notes.text: A security update is now available for Red Hat JBoss Enterprise Application Platform 8.0. Red Hat Product Security has rated this update as having a security impact of Moderate. A Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) base score, which gives a detailed severity rating, is available for each vulnerability from the CVE link(s) in the References section.
notes.title: Topic

notes.text:
Red Hat JBoss Enterprise Application Platform 8 is a platform for Java applications based on the WildFly application runtime. This release of Red Hat JBoss Enterprise Application Platform 8.0.2 serves as a replacement for Red Hat JBoss Enterprise Application Platform 8.0.1, and includes bug fixes and enhancements. See the Red Hat JBoss Enterprise Application Platform 8.0.2 Release Notes for information about the most significant bug fixes and enhancements included in this release.

Security Fix(es):

* jberet-core: jberet: jberet-core logging database credentials [eap-8.0.z] (CVE-2024-1102)

* eap-galleon: custom provisioning creates unsecured http-invoker [eap-8.0.z] (CVE-2023-4503)

* eap: JBoss EAP: wildfly-elytron has a SSRF security issue [eap-8.0.z] (CVE-2024-1233)

* eap: JBoss EAP: OIDC app attempting to access the second tenant, the user should be prompted to log [eap-8.0.z] (CVE-2023-6236)

For more details about the security issue(s), including the impact, a CVSS score, acknowledgments, and other related information, refer to the CVE page(s) listed in the References section.
notes.title: Details

notes.text: An improper initialization vulnerability was found in Galleon. When using Galleon to provision custom EAP or EAP-XP servers, the servers are created unsecured. This issue could allow an attacker to access remote HTTP services available from the server.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: eap-galleon: custom provisioning creates unsecured http-invoker
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

fixed: Red Hat JBoss Enterprise Application Platform 8

remediations.details:
Before applying the update, make sure all previously released errata relevant to your system have been applied.
Also, back up your existing installation, including all applications, configuration files, databases and database settings.
product_ids: Red Hat JBoss Enterprise Application Platform 8

products: Red Hat JBoss Enterprise Application Platform 8

vulnerabilities.title: eap-galleon: custom provisioning creates unsecured http-invoker

notes.text:
A flaw was found in Red Hat Enterprise Application Platform 8. When an OIDC app that serves multiple tenants attempts to access the second tenant, it should prompt the user to log in again since the second tenant is secured with a different OIDC configuration. The underlying issue is in OidcSessionTokenStore when determining if a cached token should be used or not. This logic needs to be updated to take into account the new "provider-url" option in addition to the "realm" option.

EAP-7 does not provide the vulnerable provider-url configuration option in its OIDC implementation and is not affected by this flaw.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: EAP: OIDC app attempting to access the second tenant, the user should be prompted to log

names: Jingcheng Yang and Jianjun Chen from Sichuan University and Zhongguancun Lab

notes.text: A flaw was found in` JwtValidator.resolvePublicKey` in JBoss EAP, where the validator checks jku and sends a HTTP request. During this process, no whitelisting or other filtering behavior is performed on the destination URL address, which may result in a server-side request forgery (SSRF) vulnerability.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: EAP: wildfly-elytron has a SSRF security issue
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The SSRF vulnerability in JwtValidator.resolvePublicKey is considered a moderate severity issue due to its potential to allow unauthorized internal network access and exposure of sensitive information, albeit with certain constraints. The vulnerability leverages the absence of URL whitelisting or filtering when resolving the jku header, which can be exploited to make HTTP requests to arbitrary URLs. While the immediate impact might not directly compromise sensitive data or system integrity, it opens a pathway for attackers to discover and interact with internal services, potentially leading to further exploitation. The exploitation complexity and the need for an attacker to craft a malicious JWT token mitigate the severity to a moderate level, as it requires a certain degree of knowledge and capability to execute effectively.
notes.title: Statement

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
